root.pub-comments: "Three Proto-Austronesian phonemes, *C, *N and *S, are reconstructed solely on the Formosan evidence. This well-known fact allows us to distinguish two major groups of Austronesian languages: Formosan and non-Formosan with different systems of consonants" (Peiros 2008:188).
root.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 2008. The Formosan language family. In Roger Blench, Marie Lin, Ilia Peiros, Malcolm D. Ross & Alicia Sanchez-Mazas (eds.), Past Human Migrations in East Asia Matching archaeology, linguistics and genetics, 182-210. London and New York: Routledge: Taylor and Francis Group.

child.pub-comments: "It is important to emphasize, however, that there are no phonological reasons preventing us from grouping the languages of Taiwan into a single Formosan family" (Peiros 2008:189). Peiros also states that Proto-Formosan broke off from Austronesian 4500 years ago and populated Taiwan (2008:193).
child.geography: all languages are spoken on Taiwan
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 2008. The Formosan language family. In Roger Blench, Marie Lin, Ilia Peiros, Malcolm D. Ross & Alicia Sanchez-Mazas (eds.), Past Human Migrations in East Asia Matching archaeology, linguistics and genetics, 182-210. London and New York: Routledge: Taylor and Francis Group.

child.pub-comments: For more information about Bunun dialects and etymologies, see Li 1988; for Bunun dictionaries, see Cheng 1971 and Nihira 1983.

child.pub-comments: Peiros states that Atayal and Seediq share a common proto-language, which is based on an analysis made by Li 1981 (Peiros 2008:182). For dictionaries for Atayal and Seediq, see Egerod 1980/99, Liao 2003, and Pecoraro 1977.

child.pub-comments: Node not named by author. "Due to the lack of reliable comparative data Amis and Kavalan are not yet classified" (Peiros 2008:210).

child.pub-comments: "According to the map given in the dictionary [see Fey 1986], there are four main dialects of this language, but systematic information about their differences is missing" (Peiros 2008:185).
